fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.bodyText: • An article about software that aims to preserve the anonymity of activist-photographers working in totalitarian regimes incorrectly attributed the concept to Peter Schaffer, a computer scientist and member of the team of three that developed the program. In fact Professor Shishir Nagaraja of the Indraprastha Institute of Information Technology in Delhi came up with the idea when photographers at the 2007 Burmese protests were identified and arrested by government officials who used their photographs to track their positions at the demonstrations. He then recruited Peter Schaffer and Djamilla Aouada, an imaging expert (Keeping snappers out of the picture, 4 July, page 2, G2). • A column celebrated the work of the architect George Gilbert Scott, and also mentioned some of Giles Gilbert Scott's work in architecture and design. But the latter was George's grandson, not his son as the column said (Our debt to Sir George Gilbert Scott, the unsung hero of British architecture, 8 July, page 35). • A report on the future of press regulation mentioned one suggestion that a successor body to the Press Complaints Commission could be modelled on the British Medical Association. What was meant was the regulatory body, the General Medical Council (Prime minister says days of press self-regulation are over, 9 July, page 8).
